sourceDesc.bibl: "Birth Control in India : An Interview with Mrs. Sanger" The Hindu, Jan 3, 1936

p.q: Mrs. Margaret Sanger, Chairman of the National Committee on Federal Legislation for Birth Control, New York, and President of the Birth Control International Information Centre, London, arrived in Madras, this morning, from Trivandrum.

Interviewed by “The Hindu,” she said that the object of her visit to India was to see the people and to awaken the responsibility of the medical profession to take a lead in giving correct information on birth control methods, which were an absolute necessity for better health and happiness of both mothers and children. Unless a scientific study fo the subject was taken on hand by the medical profession and proper knowledge disseminated among the people, the birth control movement would, she said, get into the hands of quacks.

Proceeding, she expressed the view that as far as she had been able to understand the position in India, she found that there was a keen interest among the people to have correct knowledge of the methods of birth control and that people were also anxious to understand the implication and the importance of the birth control movement.

What she wanted to emphasize was that the birth control movement had no desire to force the practice of birth control upon any one. But people should have birth-control knowledge. In Travancoreshe found that opposition to birth control only came from unmarried Christian women. But they must never forget that in every country it was the people who had too many children that supported the movement. People with large families, she found, were not against the movement. They knew the value of birth control. Clinics must be established for the poor people, who could not afford to consult private doctors, to impart knowledge on birth control methods. When a woman was discharged from a maternity hospital, she must be given proper advice on the necessity for “spacing” birth of children. If proper advice was given and the women were made to understand the need for birth control, she was sure, there would be an appreciable reduction in infantile and maternity morality. From a study of infantile mortality statistics, she found that in India and in some other countries as well, the death rate among the first to the four the children was 22 per cent, from fourth to the seventh children was 42 per cent and 60 per cent in the case of eleventh and twelfth children. An average Indian family must have only three children in the interest of the happiness and health of the mother and the children.

The fact that children were dying of starvation, the fact that there were people who could not get even one full meal a day and the fact that all people were not provided with the necessaries of life, these were sufficient factors in her opinion, to justify a birth control movement in India.

Referring to Gandhiji’s attitude, she stated that Gandhiji advocated continence. She would contend that this method was suitable only for a few people who possessed a true spiritual development, the growth of whose spiritual powers must have commenced years before. For the average man, she strongly advocated chemical and mechanical methods of birth control. In fact she believed that these methods would even help people to develop spiritual values, if their minds were so bent. For younger people between 21 and 35, it would be terrific hardship to practice continence, unless such people had dedicated their lives to some noble cause, involving prayer, fasting etc. She did not also believe that the mechanical methods would lead to overindulgence as was stated by some, nor would it lead to immortality. She firmly believed from the experience she had gained, that this movement tended to decrease immorality.

She urged that literature on the subject in all languages should be printed and published and mass meetings should be arranged through public health organizations. Education of the people on this subject should, she suggested by undertaken by the authorities and the public bodies. Birth control clinics should be established by the State and philanthropic persons, to give proper advice on the subject. In educational institutions, the theory of birth control from the population point of view and general health should be imparted, along with other lessons.
Mrs. Sanger will remain in Madras till the 10th inst. After visiting Mysoreand attending two conferences in Lucknow and Calcutta, she will leave for Rangoonon 2nd February.
